you only need a few entities to store the whole L1  calldata history though, as long as they can supply witnesses to other people everything is fine

author: sky.cactus
content: The fewer the number of any class of people who are required for network health, the easier it is to censor that group of people.  In the extreme case, if there is a single entity holding Ethereum state/history, it becomes trivial to censor Ethereum by just targeting that one entity.  With 2 entities, it becomes harder to censor, but still well within the realm of possibility.  The more people that need to be censored for the censorship to be effective, the harder it is to effectively censor the platform.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is why some of us go to great lengths to try to make it so *anyone* can run an Ethereum client, because we want to be very certain that censorship is not realistic, even for a state actor.
